The GOES-R series of satellites can improve near-term solar forecasting by 15 minutes. We develop deep auto-regressive models using convolutional neural networks (CNN) and long short-term memory networks (LSTM) that are globally trained on raw spatio-temporal data from GOES-R satellites. This self-supervised model provides estimates of future solar irradiance that can be fed into a regression model trained on smaller site-specific solar data to provide near-term solar PV forecasts at the site. The regression model implicitly accounts for site-specific characteristics, such as capacity, panel tilt, and orientation, while the self-supervised CNN-LSTM model captures global atmospheric patterns affecting a site's solar irradiation.

Results across 25 solar sites show the utility of self-supervised modeling by providing accurate near-term forecasts with errors close to those of a model using current ground-truth observations.

Introduction:
Energy generation from renewable sources surpassed coal-fired generation in the U.S. for the first time in 2019 (EIA, 2020). The U.S. Energy Information Administration projects that the share of renewable sources, such as wind and solar, in the electricity generation mix will double to almost 42% by 2050, with solar generation poised to account for almost 80% of this increase (EIA, 2021). A significant portion of solar energy comes from small-scale rooftop residential solar installations, including private homes and businesses. This decentralized and intermittent energy generation by millions of individual users alters the grid's supply and demand balance.

The underlying problem is the uncertainty associated with solar energy, which has an infinite ramp rate – its output can rise and fall instantaneously. In contrast, conventional thermal generators have a finite ramp rate. To balance electricity supply and demand, utilities often keep generators on "spinning reserve," increasing energy costs and carbon emissions. Accurate near-term solar forecasts can reduce the need for spinning reserves by enabling utilities to better plan when to activate generators.

Near-term forecasts can help grid operators plan and balance electricity generation and consumption (Wu et al., 2015; Haupt et al., 2019). They can also aid in energy market optimization (Kaur et al., 2016), residential power planning, and grid defection (Bansal & Irwin, 2019), and lower the risks associated with using intermittently available solar power (Quan et al., 2015).

While utility-scale solar sites may invest in custom models and forecasts, solar is becoming highly distributed, motivating a more automated approach. Solar generation is affected by a site's physical characteristics and atmospheric conditions. While physical characteristics have well-known physical models (Chen & Irwin, 2017), modeling and forecasting atmospheric phenomena are more difficult and often the largest sources of error (Yang et al., 2012; Sanders et al., 2017; Chen et al., 2018; Bansal & Irwin, 2020a; Siddiqui et al., 2019).

Ground-level weather monitoring stations can be sparsely located, making machine learning models from multispectral satellite data a more accessible approach for near-term solar forecasting. This approach is promising for forecasting solar PV output, which strongly correlates with solar irradiance (Raza et al., 2016). Numerical Weather Prediction algorithms (Gamarro et al., 2019; Chen et al., 2017; Tiwari et al., 2018; Mathiesen & Kleissl, 2011) can leverage satellite data to improve forecasting accuracy.
